messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: this is cool
messages.msgSnippet: Keith, Thanks, I figured that you would be all over this one. Jim __________________________________________ The knife style is called Bade-Bade or Battig or
messages.messageBody:
Keith,
Thanks, I figured that you would be all over this one.

Jim


__________________________________________
The knife style is called Bade-Bade or Battig or Roentjau or I have
seen it written roentgon or something close to that. It is a Malayan
knife. Sometimes they are single and sometimes double edged. They
can be found in the Celebes, Acheen, West Borneo, Sumatra and I am
sure Indonesia. I am certain that this particular blade is a
Japanese blade that was modified to fit into this style of mounting.
They Malay are a seafaring people who did business with virtually
everyone in SE Asia and the Pacific Isles. It is entirely possible
the blade was traded for, bought or even stolen as pirate booty. It
is an interesting amalgamation of styles! I have never seen one like
this, but I am not surprised considering the trading and pirating
skills of the Malay people!
>
>

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: this is cool
messages.msgSnippet: ... hard edge rather than a ha/hamon.  I also don t think I ve ever seen one with a habaki.  Perhaps it s a cultural/technological hybrid, but I don t think
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...>
wrote:
> The better Indonesian blades that I have seen have an "inserted"
hard edge rather than a ha/hamon. I also don't think I've ever seen
one with a habaki. Perhaps it's a cultural/technological hybrid, but
I don't think that the mounting is too old. But, nihontostudy this
is not...
>
> Jim
>
>
>
> Remember there was a "colony" of Bushi living in South Asia
before
> 1600. OTOH couldn't this be a completely indigenous product?
Afterall
> they had the same technology...
>
__________________________________________
The knife style is called Bade-Bade or Battig or Roentjau or I have
seen it written roentgon or something close to that. It is a Malayan
knife. Sometimes they are single and sometimes double edged. They
can be found in the Celebes, Acheen, West Borneo, Sumatra and I am
sure Indonesia. I am certain that this particular blade is a
Japanese blade that was modified to fit into this style of mounting.
They Malay are a seafaring people who did business with virtually
everyone in SE Asia and the Pacific Isles. It is entirely possible
the blade was traded for, bought or even stolen as pirate booty. It
is an interesting amalgamation of styles! I have never seen one like
this, but I am not surprised considering the trading and pirating
skills of the Malay people!
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] this is cool
messages.msgSnippet: Remember there was a colony of Bushi living in South Asia before 1600. OTOH couldn t this be a completely indigenous product? Afterall they had the same
messages.messageBody:
Remember there was a "colony" of Bushi living in South Asia before
1600. OTOH couldn't this be a completely indigenous product? Afterall
they had the same technology...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] this is cool
messages.msgSnippet: The better Indonesian blades that I have seen have an inserted hard edge rather than a ha/hamon.  I also don t think I ve ever seen one with a habaki.
messages.messageBody:
The better Indonesian blades that I have seen have an "inserted" hard edge rather than a ha/hamon. I also don't think I've ever seen one with a habaki. Perhaps it's a cultural/technological hybrid, but I don't think that the mounting is too old. But, nihontostudy this is not...

Jim



Remember there was a "colony" of Bushi living in South Asia before
1600. OTOH couldn't this be a completely indigenous product? Afterall
they had the same technology...
-t


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] this is cool
messages.msgSnippet: The general shape and style look Indonesian, but they were capable of much better carving and often used higher quality wood.  They also mounted their
messages.messageBody:
The general shape and style look Indonesian, but they were capable of much better carving and often used higher quality wood. They also mounted their single-edged blades in edge-down orientation. Even given that the nakago was changed, the shape of the blade is unusual and the shape of that habaki is also pretty odd.

Keith M., what do you think?

Jim



Yeah, I think the nakago was altered. David commented that it looked like a
kris, which is Indonesian.



Gordon



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] this is cool
messages.msgSnippet: Yeah, I think the nakago was altered. David commented that it looked like a kris, which is Indonesian. Gordon ... From: Richard Turner
messages.messageBody:
Yeah, I think the nakago was altered. David commented that it looked like a
kris, which is Indonesian.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@...]
Sent: Friday, November 21, 2003 4:10 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] this is cool



Gordon.
I thought it had a more European look to it ?, not that I mean
it is a muromachi thing or anything, it looks like it is early 1900's or
late 1800's, just thought it looked kinda fun. Would a nagako be made like
that or do you think it was altered for the fittings ?.

Maybe it's just a novelty piece.

cheers mate

Rich

messages.msgSnippet: Hi David, indeed, there is a great similarity. I just wonder how a tanto got into to something like that. I also had the same thought as Milt, it looks like an
messages.messageBody:
Hi David, indeed, there is a great similarity. I just wonder how a tanto got into to something like that. I also had the same thought as Milt, it looks like an old European pistol.

Rich
